text: Yeah. So the BAA spread is what I was talking about. So this is the investment grade spread just over a very long period of time. It's very tight right now. Don't get me wrong. Actually, within high yields, we'll talk specifics right now. So it's early April 2021, right? CCC spread is very tight right now. And that's actually what's driving the overall high yield spread tighter. The BB spread, which is the high end of high yield is, and actually, by the way, investment grade spreads are also pretty tight. The high end of high yield is actually tight, but not much tighter than it's been. It's not at extremes. And that's actually half the market. So that's really being driven by the CCC spread, which ends up when you take an average being really important because it's a smaller part of the market, maybe 20% of the market. But because the spreads are so wide, they disproportionately affect the average spread. So there is a composition element to this. But let's go back to this idea of when do you buy credit? Why do you buy credit? And how do you make money? What I say now is a great time to drive CCC bonds with spread tight? No, because that tends to be very, when the market cycles, those get slammed. And so your upside downside of that makes no sense. But if you're trying to invest in something that's going to be able to at least minimize your drawdowns while giving you some return, you probably want to invest in relatively safe credit or higher quality credit at exactly times when spreads are tight. And I know that's counterintuitive, but tight spreads. I mean, even if you have a credit, you're not going to be able to get a lot of returns. And the reason why that happens is because the spread isn't necessarily the best indicator of credit returns. Credit returns are driven by the business cycle. So when you have a business cycle, you have a business cycle when the yield curve is inverted. You have a business cycle when actually spreads are starting to not going, doing what they're doing right now, which is going down, right? They're going up and going up quickly and triple C's are going. So triple C's going tighter, means that safer quality. You're further away from a credit event. You typically see actually the Fed starting to lower rates even more because they're concerned and they've raised rates and they're lowering them because now they're concerned about the economy and they're seeing data and they're in the time none of those things are happening so it's actually a fairly benign environment there's a good argument you should be long risk right now if you were actually following that methodology but also if you don't want to be a hundred percent equities you want to make some return and something that's going to give you lower drawdowns credit's good so this counterintuitive thing that actually maybe the right time to buy credit is when spreads are kind of tight just don't go buy the stuff that should never have tight spreads right that's and that and that's what i'd say about right now now i'd prefer if spreads were 800 but we don't have that opportunity right now
